channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Parkinson’s may begin in the gut, study says, adding to growing body of evidence
item.description: The study, published in JAMA Network Open, found that people with upper gastrointestinal conditions — in particular, ulcers or other types of damage to the lining of the esophagus, stomach or upper part of the small intestine — were far more likely to develop Parkinson’s disease later in life.

item.title: Hunter Biden pleads guilty to federal tax charges, could face hefty fine and prison sentence
item.description: President Joe Biden’s son entered a last-minute guilty plea on the day jury selection was supposed to begin in his federal trial. He could face up to 17 years in prison and fines of up to $1.3 million, a judge in Los Angeles said.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How does divorced parent adjust to having less time with son?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How does divorced parent adjust to having less time with son?

item.title: New York Times publisher A.G. Sulzberger writes in an op-ed: The quiet war against press freedom could come to America. Here’s how.
item.description: Some foreign leaders have ruthlessly curtailed journalism. American politicians could draw from their playbook, Sulzberger writes.

item.title: Hunter Biden offers plea in tax case, in effort to avoid second criminal trial
item.description:
President Joe Biden’s son Hunter tried to resolve his federal tax case Thursday morning as jury selection was about to begin, offering an Alford plea in which he maintains he is innocent but acknowledges that the prosecution’s evidence would likely result in a guilty verdict.
The judge adjourned the court proceedings until 11 a.m. Pacific time so prosecutors could consider the plea offer.

item.title: A fictional train in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Ugandan Olympic runner Rebecca Cheptegei dies after she was set on fire by her ex-boyfriend
item.description: Cheptegei is the third high-profile athlete to be killed in a domestic violence incident in Kenya, where she was based.

item.title: Georgia school shooting. Liz Cheney. Trump hearing. U.S. Steel. Toxic plastic. Space spectacle. ‘Game of Thrones.’ Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The FBI learned of Ga. high school shooting suspect a year ago and sheriffs had questioned the teen and his father, agency says
item.description: FBI agents received anonymous tips over a year ago about online threats allegedly made by the suspect now accused of killing four and injuring nine others at Apalachee High School. Jackson County Sheriff's officers interviewed the teen suspect and his father, who said hunting guns were kept in the house but his son did not have unsupervised access to them. Local schools were alerted about the tips, the FBI said.

item.title: Liz Cheney, in a break with the Republican Party, says she will vote for Democratic nominee Kamala Harris
item.description: Cheney, the former congresswoman who served as vice chair of the House committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, made the announcement in North Carolina, which is considered to be one of the battleground states that could help decide the election.

item.title: Georgia school shooting suspect in custody is a 14-year-old student; two students and two teachers were killed, officials say
item.description: Police identified a teenager as the suspect in a shooting at Georgia’s Apalachee High School that killed four people Wednesday.

item.title: Biden is preparing to block Nippon Steel’s purchase of U.S. Steel in stunning move, people familiar with the matter say
item.description: The move would formally block Nippon Steel’s proposed $14.9 billion acquisition of U.S. Steel, according to three people with knowledge of the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The proposed deal has been under investigation by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States.

item.title: At least two killed and several wounded in Georgia high school shooting, according to a law enforcement official
item.description: Several others were wounded in the shooting at Apalachee High School, about 35 miles northeast of Atlanta. A suspect is in custody, the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said.

item.title: These are the asteroids that scare scientists. Are we prepared for them?
item.description: These are the asteroids that scare scientists. Are we prepared for them?

item.title: Cooking chat: Why not use bagged shredded cheese in recipes? We’re answering your questions now.
item.description: Cooking chat: Why not use bagged shredded cheese in recipes? We’re answering your questions now.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Imbalance in visits with in-laws vs. parents starts to chafe
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Imbalance in visits with in-laws vs. parents starts to chafe

item.title: Meta’s oversight body says ‘from the river to the sea’ isn’t necessarily hate speech, a decision likely to fuel Israel-Gaza debates
item.description: The company-funded oversight body ruled the social media giant shouldn’t automatically take down posts using the phrase, a decades-old rallying cry for Palestinian nationalism that has reignited debate about the boundaries of acceptable speech. The clash has forced the company to closely examine its content rules amid scrutiny from Jewish groups that have accused it of allowing antisemitism to surge and criticism from pro-Palestinian groups, which argue Meta has stifled political critique amid a deadly war.

item.title: It was pitched as ‘an extraordinary opportunity’ to protect the planet and people. The Post found deep failures.
item.description: C-Quest Capital said its stoves could improve people’s lives and reduce carbon emissions. But an investigation by The Washington Post in Mozambique reveals that the company promised more than it could deliver — a further hit to a troubled offsets market used by BP, Shell and other major corporations to meet their climate goals.

item.title: An unsettling new milestone for this city in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Russian strike. Trump vs. Harris. Gaza talks. School cop. Landslides. Cellphone study. Titanic. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba resigns amid government shake-up
item.description: Kuleba’s exit follows those of other high-ranking officials in Ukraine this week. Kuleba, who has been in the role since 2020, has been a key voice in Ukraine’s drive to receive foreign weapons and to push allies to loosen restrictions on how they are used.

item.title: A louder voice in fighting abortion bans: Men in red states
item.description:
Two years after the Supreme Court overturned federal protections for abortion, growing numbers of men in deeply conservative states are speaking out in defense of reproductive rights because of the harrowing experiences they’ve seen wives or partners go through when pregnancies went tragically awry.
They have an integral role in the debate, a legal expert says: “Men telling their own stories … is going to be a big way to change hearts and minds.”

item.title: Justice Dept. charges Hamas leaders with terrorism, citing Oct. 7 attack, and is investigating killing of Hersh Goldberg-Polin
item.description: Attorney General Merrick Garland stressed that Hamas was responsible for the Oct. 7 deaths in southern Israel and said the United States will investigate the killing of Goldberg-Polin, 23, whose body was found in Gaza last week, as an act of terrorism.

item.title: A school resource officer admitted to sexually abusing two students. A South Carolina judge just sentenced him to probation.
item.description: Richland County Sheriff's Deputy Jamel Bradley kept his job for years despite multiple complaints of sexual misconduct with teen girls, a Washington Post investigation found. The judge ordered Bradley to register as a sex offender, against the recommendation of prosecutors.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Wife ‘ticks every box,’ but newlywed wants out of their marriage
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Wife ‘ticks every box,’ but newlywed wants out of their marriage

item.title: Post Opinions asked seven writers to find an amazing story from deep within government. First up, Michael Lewis’s discovery.
item.description: The 2024 conversation has been driven by a handful of names. Trump. Harris. Biden. Vance. Walz. These individuals have put themselves forward to lead our government. But who really is our government? What is it made of? And what is at stake when politicians say they want to expand or dismantle it? To find out, we set seven stellar writers loose on the federal bureaucracy.

item.title: A Post investigation into Xi’s visit to San Francisco reveals how China extended its repression into a U.S. city
item.description: Chinese diplomats and pro-China diaspora groups based in the United States organized demonstrations in San Francisco that harassed and silenced protesters opposed to Beijing’s policies, including through violence, during Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s visit to the city in November.

item.title: A new take on a head-scratching story in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Ukrainian president says at least 41 people killed in Russian missile strike at the Communications Institute in Poltava
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said 180 people were injured when two ballistic missiles struck. The Defense Ministry said the time between the alarm and the impact was so short that many people were caught trying to reach shelters and were trapped under the rubble.

item.title: Harris-Biden rally. Israel protests. Seized plane. China crackdown. Coronavirus shots. ‘Spy’ whale. Paralympics. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Your ride is here. Take a trip with Uber driver Jon Rigsby in this comic from the Shifts series.
item.description: The loneliness of the short-distance driver

item.title: How Trump helped spark a culture war with his 1776 Commission on patriotism
item.description: In his final months in office, President Donald Trump’s aides resisted as the president sought to ban the New York Times’ 1619 Project from the nation’s classrooms. Instead, he created a new commission on patriotism – and launched a culture debate that would reenergize his base after he left office. The little-noticed episode helps explain how Trump might view education if reelected.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband declares daughter, 15, will ‘always be an underachiever’
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband declares daughter, 15, will ‘always be an underachiever’

item.title: Crash of ‘dark’ tanker exposes the dangers of China’s thirst for cheap oil
item.description: To bypass Western financial systems and shipping services, China relies on a fleet of aging, substandard tankers that operate illicitly, analysts say. The ships pose major safety threats and have alarmed global shipping groups.

item.title: A school cop was repeatedly accused of sexual misconduct with female students. He kept his job for years.
item.description: In South Carolina, Richland County Sheriff’s Deputy Jamel Bradley continued working as a school resource officer despite multiple complaints that he was preying on teenage girls at Spring Valley High. Bradley, a former college basketball star, is now facing sex crime charges.

item.title: The origins of Labor Day in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: Hostage deaths. Trump vs. Harris. Far-right victory. Hotel strike. Elon Musk. Hot summer. Cash incentive. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: U.S., with Qatar and Egypt, preparing final ‘take it or leave it’ deal between Israel and Hamas
item.description: The effort was underway before Israeli officials discovered the bodies of six hostages. But U.S. officials said the discovery adds new urgency to striking a deal, and that if Israel and Hamas do not agree to their final proposal it could mark the end of American-led negotiations.

item.title: What it’s really like to take the train from California to New York
item.description: This summer, comic artist Christine Mi rode two Amtrak trains across 12 states and 3,397 miles, meandering her way alongside deserts, forests, mountains, rivers; through coal plants, suburban backyards, vast cornfields, and the occasional Big American City. See her illustrated Amtrak journey.

item.title: Protesters flood the streets of Israel, labor union announces general strike after recovery of six dead hostages in Gaza
item.description: Families of hostages and their supporters are trying to pressure Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to agree to a deal with Hamas to bring home the remaining captives. The six hostages recovered by the military Saturday, including Israeli American Hersh Goldberg-Polin, were killed by their captors shortly before troops found them, Israel’s Health Ministry said.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Do you spend money like a Gen Z-er, millennial or boomer? Take our quiz to see which generation you align most with.
item.description: Your spending says a lot about your income bracket and whether you have kids. But there are also generational influences — and a growing gap between how older and younger generations spend money. Take this quiz to find out if you spend money more like an 18-year-old, a 78-year-old or somewhere in between.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Mass polio vaccinations begin in Gaza amid limited pauses in fighting, U.N. says
item.description: The campaign to vaccinate more than 600,000 children against polio began in Gaza on Sunday, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees and the World Health Organization said. Israel said it would allow a "humanitarian corridor" for vaccination personnel and designate safe areas for administering the shots.

item.title: Israeli American hostage Hersh Goldberg-Polin confirmed dead by family and White House
item.description: The family of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, 23, who was kidnapped by Hamas on Oct. 7, said he had been killed. Their statement came after the Israeli military announced it had located a number of dead bodies in Gaza.

item.title: Scientists are finding biases built into the Marshmallow Test and other common predictors of children’s success
item.description: Developmental psychology aims to elucidate the “universals” in how the human mind develops but has often gleaned those insights by studying White, middle-class children from Western countries. So, if a child from a poor family or different culture doesn’t perform well, is the fault in the child or the test?

item.title: A sexual harassment scandal dogged Corey Lewandowski. Now he’s officially back in Donald Trump’s fold.
item.description: Lewandowski, Trump’s first 2016 campaign manager, was reported to the police by three women who alleged unwanted physical contact, including a GOP donor in 2021 whose claims led Trump to call her directly, she said. Trump’s decision to bring back Lewandowski this month as a senior adviser shows his high tolerance for allies with political liabilities as long as they remain loyal.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My dad says my brother gets the family estate because of ‘tradition’
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My dad says my brother gets the family estate because of ‘tradition’

item.title: A reporter detailed tennis star Alexander Zverev’s alleged abuse of women — and is paying for it
item.description: Accusations of emotional and physical abuse by Zverev — which he has repeatedly denied — cast a shadow over his ascent. But the resulting stories may have created more troubles for their writer, Ben Rothenberg, as he grapples with a costly lawsuit.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
